Posts.Content: Let me reiterate something that was mentioned a few posts back. Dr. Patrick Walsh virtually invented the radical prostatectomy procedure at Johns Hopkins (where I had mine done). His book, "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer", is considered the Bible for PC. Very well written, very understandable by the layman, even humorous at times. It is a must-read. Get it today from Amazon. It will answer virtually all of your questions and give you a high degree of comfort as you learn that this is highly treatable, the how's, and the why's. dave

Posts.Title: 6 Months out of surgery robotic prostatectomy

Posts.Content: I did robotic last July. They got it all and I've been great since, with just a little incontinence, mostly after bike riding. I'm no expert, but, in regards surgery vs radiation, the killer for me is that if the radiation doesn't work, surgery is off the table. Then what do you do? If you do surgery and there's a recurrence, you can do salvage radiation which, to my knowledge, is most often effective. I would recommend surgery, especially the robotic, as would, I believe, most guys here. Mostly good results, not that bad an experience, and preserves future options.

Posts.Content: Hey all- I'm 9 days post-RP. All has gone well. This morning, though, as I sit outside with coffee and laptop, I feel/see what appears to be a tan-colored mushy-looking stuff oozing out from the tip of my penis around the catheter. Not a lot; maybe the size of 2 BB's. And I feel a slight "need to go", though I've felt that before and it has passed. Been filling the urine bag well, and the urine looks healthy. Any thoughts on this? Wondering if it might be a sign of infection, but other than that feeling of needing to go, nothing else "feels bad". Thoughts? thanks- dave

I'm guessing that first biopsy probably missed some bad cores or that the suspicious core "turned" bad. And, with that rate of increase, I'm also guessing surgery is in my future. Any thoughts? thanks- dave

Posts.Title: Oh, blah...

Posts.Content: Had my RP with Dr. Allaf at JH three weeks ago today. And it's almost like it never happened. Very slight incontinence, but that's it. I'm hankering to play some tennis, but I 'spose I'd better wait a bit longer. I was told nothing to eat for 24 hours prior except clear stuff like coffee (yay), clear jello or popsicles (still have some of those left). They should have given you a prep sheet which describes all this. Bottle of magnesium citrate the evening before, then NOTHING after midnight, except for 8 ounces of water about 4 hours before surgery. And, yeah, the enema, but that was just no big deal. I described my JH experience. Look for the post "RP the day before yesterday" by dshinnick. Good luck! It'll be behind you before you know it.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Slide Show

Posts.Content: My first biopsy a year ago: 1/12 cores, 5%. G6 Second biopsy a week ago: 5/12 cores. 2x40%, 1x20%, 2x5%. Still a G6. Negative DRE. Over that period of time, PSA went from 5.2 to 6.0. So, I'm figuring on visiting "the knife" and just have it gone. We're full-time motorhomers on a trip up the east coast right now. I figure maybe by early September we'll be in the northeast. I can find a good surgeon, drop anchor in a park for a month, get the surgery, and have the month to recover; more if necessary. Then resume our travels back south for the winter. Coupla questions: 1. Does it seem right that, having the PC grow like that in a year, I would still be a G6? 2. When I told the Doc I'd probably have the surgery in 6 months or so, he seemed fine with it. Does that seem ok, or should I do it sooner? Obviously, I don't want to risk it growing outside the prostate. But, if the G6 is accurate, I'm thinking that won't be a concern. Thoughts? Advice? Thanks- Dave

Posts.Title: RP the day before yesterday

Posts.Content: I know I was anxious to read about other guys' experiences regarding what I was about to go through, so I guess it's my turn to share. Thursday morning, two days ago, I showed up for my RP with Dr. Mohamed Allaf at Johns Hopkins in Baltimore. Highly competent doctor and hospital; I considered myself very fortunate to have insurance which allowed me to be treated by this esteemed institution. The pre-op was insignificant except that person after person kept asking me the same questions! An abundance of caution, they said, and I guess I can be grateful for that. I was wheeled into the OR and was amazed at the equipment, the technology, the number of folks in the room! I felt somewhat humbled that all these experts would give of their expertise to help solve my problem. I saw Mr. Robot sitting in the corner, his mechanical arms just waiting for permission to begin his life-saving work on my behalf. JH is a teaching hospital and there were several residents there to observe and learn. I was glad that my experience will, through them, benefit others. They started attaching things to my legs, and arms, and chest. Nothing hurt. Then I was told to start sucking pure oxygen from a plastic mask held over my mouth. They apologized that it smelled so plasticky. All the JH folks were forever apologizing for the most mundane things; they know what a trying experience this is and they try to make it go as comfortably as possible. After 4 or 5 sucks of pure oxygen, I heard "We're going to put you to sleep now". And they did. I woke up in recovery. My biggest complaint was sleepiness! I could barely keep my eyes open. So, I stopped trying, and drifted in and out for awhile. I felt for the catheter, which was in place, which told me they had completed the operation and didn't have to abort for some reason. Zero nausea, and relatively little pain. So thankful for that! After awhile I was wheeled up to my (private) room. Nurses came and went, I was on a continuous IV of fluids to keep me hydrated and peeing, and really the worst pain I felt was in the small of my back from the bed! Maybe it was just at a bad angle, or too firm. I can't blame them; I sometimes get a bit of back pain while lying in bed at home, or in my chaise lounge. I wasn't in the mood to read so I hooked my phone up to power (should have brought an extension cord), and began listening to podcasts. After an hour or two a nurse commented that later on I should try walking, which I knew was important from this forum. So I said, "I'm ready; let's do it!". So she helped me up, closed up the rear-view of my hospital gown, and I was off and walking. Made it around 2 1/2 times before I figured that was enough for the first time. I began passing gas after a couple of hours, which the nurses celebrated like it was my birthday. They brought me an frozen Orange Mango treat which went down just fine. End of day 0. Slept very little overnight. That minor back pain, plus I just wasn't as sleepy as I thought I would have been! Oh well. I watched the clock make its relentless march toward daylight. Good thing I was loaded up with podcasts. Nurses came in to empty the urine bag, replace my IV bag, and take one blood sample. The overnight nurse seemed perfectly competent, but...well...kinda ghoulish. Guess that can happen when you have a steady diet of "graveyard" shifts. The next morning I ordered coffee and cream of wheat. Both were small servings, but went down just fine with no negative effects. One of the attending physicians, who had been in the OR, said that Dr. Allaf reported that the prostate came out whole, with no evidence that the cancer had escaped, and that he was very pleased. Well, if he's pleased, so am I! And he informed me that I would be able to go home that day, so only one night in the hospital, instead of the planned two nights. The rest of the day was pretty uneventful. Nurses, bag emptying, walking, podcasts, and some book reading. Around 4PM the nurse gave the tutorial on catheter care and the like. Easy. The wife came about five o'clock, I was wheeled out to the car, and off we went. End of day 1. It's now 9:30AM, day 2. I slept quite well last night, which was really nice. Emptied the quite-full bag once during the night, and again this morning. Went out for a walk, got tired after about 10 minutes, and came back to my recliner, my coffee and my laptop. So, bottom line? It ain't pleasant. I don't think this experience will ever become an attraction at Disneyland. But it's not terrible. You just have to remind yourself that "tough times don't last; tough people do". And most importantly, keep reminding yourself that you're very likely to now be cancer-free, and that this is NOT that great a price to pay to be able to say that. I kept thinking, "You clod. Why did *you* have to be one of the one-in-seven who gets this?". Look for the occasional light side, try to laugh at yourself just a little, and know that, as everyone says here, it will get better, day by day. Dave

Posts.Title: RP the day before yesterday

Posts.Content: Ah, best wishes Mike. Chin up, keep a good spirit, and you'll make it through just fine. This is just a speedbump on the highway of life. Be seriously grateful that technology has made this almost a non-event, compared to what they went through just a few years ago. I'm looking forward to reading the story of YOUR journey to the "other side"! dave

Posts.Title: Ouch!

Posts.Content: Oh, Lord. First of all, who else in the world cares if you buy an enema? Others care far less about us than we think they do. This is just a good opportunity to learn to be bold and unashamed of who you are and what's happening to you. Don't wonder, and don't care, what others think. Second, don't sweat the biopsy. It's really no big deal. I've had several. Sure, it's new, and unfamiliar, and may be a bit uncomfortable; so what. Afterwards, go treat yourself to a Whopper. I just finished reading a book on the "Hell Week" that prospective Navy SEAL's have to go through. Wow. Made the little inconveniences that come my way seem pretty darned insignificant. It's no big deal, you're much stronger than you think you are, and you'll get through it just fine. The only REAL mistake you can make is to not have it done. Now, THAT can kill you. Just get 'er done. You'll be fine.

Posts.Content: I emailed my RP surgeon and he said I could do tennis after a month! I guess he was just impressed with my youth, energy and vigor. :0) Yeah, I'll take it easy for awhile, see what happens. Been good so far today. Oh well. Guess I can't have a completely problem-free recovery! dave

Posts.Title: Ouch!

Posts.Content: ....though this membership I could have passed on.... :0) Had my first PSA on a whim, just for the heck of it, about 2 months ago. 2 weeks ago had a 12-sample biopsy, during which DRE was normal, as was the visual inspection. I'm scheduled for a CT abdomen and pelvis, and a bone scan next week. The rest is in my signature. New to all this, of course, with a few questions. In my biopsy results, in the little graph showing the location of the two bad areas, there's a dark oval in the upper center, which is not labelled. What is that? Also, as far as reading is concerned, I see folks talking a lot about Dr. Walsh's, "Guide to Surviving...". But I see it's over a year old, and a lot can change in a year. Is there a newer resource book which is recommended reading? For example, on Amazon, I see: "Prostate Cancer Breakthroughs 2014: New Tests, New Treatments, Better Options", by Jay Cohen. Any thoughts? Thanks- Dave

Posts.Title: Curious about experience

Posts.Content: I am five weeks post-RP today, and have been doing exceedingly well. Almost like it never happened. But....within just the last couple of days I've been getting a dull ache in the general area of the two right-most incisions. It comes and goes, is never a sharp pain, and does not respond to touch; it doesn't hurt when I press on it. But I would say the dull ache can sometimes be significant; maybe a 3 on a scale of 10. Certainly enough to keep me off the tennis court. If it had been sore ever since the procedure, I would think it's just being slow to heal. But up til a few days ago I had no pain there at all. I'm contemplating making an appt at a local walk-in clinic (we're motorhomers and don't have a regular MD), but thought I'd run it by the gang here first. Any thoughts / experience like this?

Posts.Title: Ouch!

Posts.Content: Oh, Lord. First of all, who else in the world cares if you buy an enema? Others care far less about us than we think they do. This is just a good opportunity to learn to be bold and unashamed of who you are and what's happening to you. Don't wonder, and don't care, what others think. Second, don't sweat the biopsy. It's really no big deal. I've had several. Sure, it's new, and unfamiliar, and may be a bit uncomfortable; so what. Afterwards, go treat yourself to a Whopper. I just finished reading a book on the "Hell Week" that prospective Navy SEAL's have to go through. Wow. Made the little inconveniences that come my way seem pretty darned insignificant. It's no big deal, you're much stronger than you think you are, and you'll get through it just fine. The only REAL mistake you can make is to not have it done. Now, THAT can kill you. Just get 'er done. You'll be fine.

Posts.Content: I am five weeks post-RP today, and have been doing exceedingly well. Almost like it never happened. But....within just the last couple of days I've been getting a dull ache in the general area of the two right-most incisions. It comes and goes, is never a sharp pain, and does not respond to touch; it doesn't hurt when I press on it. But I would say the dull ache can sometimes be significant; maybe a 3 on a scale of 10. Certainly enough to keep me off the tennis court. If it had been sore ever since the procedure, I would think it's just being slow to heal. But up til a few days ago I had no pain there at all. I'm contemplating making an appt at a local walk-in clinic (we're motorhomers and don't have a regular MD), but thought I'd run it by the gang here first. Any thoughts / experience like this?

Posts.Title: Ouch!

Posts.Content: Diagnosed over a year ago. 5.4PSA, 1 core/12, 5%, 1 suspicious. G6 Three weeks ago, 6.0PSA, 5 cores/12: [emailprotected]%, [emailprotected]%, [emailprotected]%. G6. Negative DRE. Three questions. 1. Does it seem reasonable that I could go from 1 core to 5 cores, in about a year, and still be a G6? I know the first biopsy might have missed one...or two....but to go from 1 to 5 indicates to me a more aggressive growth than a G6 would indicate. 2. I'm planning on RP in about 4 months. Ok to wait that long? Don't want to risk it escaping the capsule, of course. I know I need to wait minimum 6 weeks from biopsy, not sure if 4 months is too long. 3. A week or so after the second biopsy, semen was very dark, quantity about "normal". A week later, still dark, but quantity considerably less. Today, about three weeks since biopsy, still dark, quantity about 1/3 of normal. Any thoughts on this? Thanks much, guys! dave

Posts.Title: Need help with path report

Posts.Content: Got the path report back via email. Doc hasn't called to interpret, so I thought I'd post it here. All looks good to me, the total amateur, except maybe the note near the end about the "one possible lymph node". Can the experts here review this and tell me what you see? Also, up to this point we'd thought it was only G6. Thanks- INTERPRETATION AND DIAGNOSIS: (cxw) 07/21/2015 @ 04:34 pm 1) PROSTATE AND SEMINAL VESICLES (RADICAL PROSTATECTOMY): HISTOLOGIC TYPE: Adenocarcinoma (conventional, NOS) GLEASON SCORE - DOMINANT NODULE: 3+4=7 PERCENT PATTERN 4: 5% TUMOR EXTENT: Moderate LOCATION: (DOMINANT NODULE): Left, right, posterolateral, posterior, mid, base LOCAL EXTENT: Organ confined MARGINS: Negative SEMINAL VESICLE INVASION: None LYMPHATIC (SMALL VESSEL) INVASION : Absent EXTENT OF INVASION (7th Edition, AJCC, Staging): PRIMARY TUMOR: pT2: Organ confined throughout REGIONAL LYMPH NODES: pNx Cannot be assessed SUMMARY MARGINS: Negative TUMOR: A REPRESENTATIVE TUMOR BLOCK IS: 1RDP NORMAL: A REPRESENTATIVE NORMAL BLOCK IS: 1LAA 2) ANTERIOR FAT PAD (BIOPSY): BENIGN FIBROADIPOSE TISSUE, NEGATIVE FOR TUMOR. CONGLI WANG, M.D. CW* GROSS DESCRIPTION PART #1: PROSTATE AND SV (leh) Resident Pathologist: WHITE, M.D. 07/16/2015 Dictated by K. GIBSON The specimen is received labeled with the patient's name and designated prostate and SV. The specimen is received fresh and is vigorously identifiable radicle prostatectomy specimen with attached bilateral seminal vesicles and vas deferentia. The prostate weighs 30.9 grams, measures 3.7 cm transversely, 3.2 cm from apex to base, and 2.3 cm from anterior to posterior. The prostate is inked black, injected with formalin, with the mid line posterior aspect marked orange, the left posterolateral aspect marked blue and the right posterolateral aspect marked green. The prostate is serially sectioned from apex to base and 4 cm punch cores are harvested, which are present in slices A - D in the bilateral posterior prostate. At the time of harvest, a palpable 0.4 cm mass is identified within the right posterior prostate. At time of grossing the prostatic parenchyma is pale pink tan, lobulated and rubbery. A discrete mass is not identified. Approximately 96% of the prostate gland is submitted. SUMMARY OF SECTIONS: 2 - RVDSV, LVDSV - 2/EACH 1 - PUM - M 2 - PUM2 AND PUM3 - M/EACH 4 - RDUMA, RDUMB, LDUMA, LDUMB - 2/EACH EXCEPT FOR LDUMA 3 6 - RAA - RFA - 1/EACH 6 - RAP - RFP - 1/EACH 6 - LAA - LFA - 1/EACH 6 - LAP - LFP - 1/EACH 33 - TOTAL - M PART #2: ANTERIOR FAT PAD (leh) Resident Pathologist: MARISSA JANINE WHITE, M.D. 07/16/2015 Dictated by M. ROBINSON The specimen is received fresh labeled with the patient's name and is designated anterior fat pad. It consists of multiple lobulated fragments of tan yellow adipose tissue measuring 3 x 2 x 0.4 cm in loose aggregate. One possible lymph node is identified measuring 1.0 x 0.3 x 0.2 cm. The specimen is entirely submitted. SUMMARY OF SECTIONS: 1 - A - (1) ONE POSSIBLE LYMPH NODE 1 - B - (M) FAT 2 - TOTAL - M Other Surgical Pathology Specimens known to the computer: S15-26 (End of Report)

Posts.Title: prostatectomy - MD Anderson on July 27th

Posts.Content: I had my first biopsy a year ago, and was asked to do a double enema the morning of. During the biopsy, the doc mentioned that he saw the effect of having done the enemas, and, as I remember, said it made it easier to do the biopsy. I have my next biopsy scheduled for Friday, and the Doc said that an enema was not necessary. Kinda makes me wonder why. Does he really think it'll be of no significant benefit? Might this make you question his competence? (though he seemed ok to me). And, should I go ahead and do it anyway? I don't mind; it wasn't that big a deal. And if it might possibly help ensure a more reliable biopsy, I'm sure willing. Thoughts? dave

Posts.Title: Enema: Yes? No? Maybe?

Posts.Content: 1. In the results of my biopsy, in the little drawing showing the 12 tested sections of the prostate, in the upper center is a dark oval which they don't identify. I don't think it's cancer-related, but inquiring minds want to know...what is that? 2. Folks refer to "negative margins" or "clear margins". What's that? 3. The biggie: I'm still not clear on the value of Active Surveillance. From what I can tell: Advantage: postpones the discomfort and side effects of treatment. Disadvantages: 1. It does not lead to a curing, or even a reduction, of the existing cancer. 2. If the cancer is greater than the biopsy(s) indicated, which several folks here have experienced, it allows it the chance to extend outside the prostate. 3. Requires regular and continuing PSA tests and, likely, biopsies. 4. It mostly just procrastinates and delays the inevitable. Am I missing anything? If I'm "ok" with the possible side effects, and if I gotta do treatment eventually, I'd rather do it now, get it over with, and not risk #2 above. Thoughts? Thanks- Dave

Posts.Title: Coupla questions

Posts.Content: Stream seems a bit weak, but certainly not 20 minutes worth! The doc put me on Flomax two weeks ago. It's all gone now, but didn't seem to change that much when I was on it. Even if it just stayed the way it is now, it's no big deal. And, about 6' 2", 205 pounds. Overall good health. We play about an hour of Pickleball (think tennis) 4-5 times a week. I've been a heavy drinker (just wine and beer) for years....and years. Went cold turkey when the PSA test came back. Wasn't hard at all. I'm glad to be off it now. I now have a small glass of red each night, for the benefit of it, but even that I could do without. Blood pressure has dropped noticeably since quitting; the automated pressure tester in Walmart says "Great!" to me now. Not on any medication but zoloft for depression. Was on Paxil for it for years, but about 1 year ago switched to Zoloft.
